title: N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 6 §§ 220-3.2 - Definitions
content:
N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 6 §§ 220-3.2 - Definitions

State Regulations
(a) For the purpose
of this Subpart, the general definitions of Part 200 and Part 201 of this Title
apply. (b) For the purpose of this

Subpart, the following definitions also apply: (1)
'Aggregate.' Any hard, inert material
used for mixing in graduated particles or fragments, including sand, gravel, crushed stone, slag, recycled asphalt, rock dust or powder. (2)
'Asphalt Cement.' A material that is used
to bind aggregate into asphalt mixture, as defined in this Subpart. Asphalt
cements can be modified to meet different criteria, such as, but not limited
to, hot and warm mix applications. (3)
'Asphalt Cement Storage Tank and Heater.'
A storage tank where asphalt cement is stored and heated before it is
transferred to the mixer. (4)
'Asphalt Mixture Manufacturing Plant.' A facility comprised of one or more

Asphalt Mixture Processing Units used to produce asphalt mixture, including but
not limited to storage silos, asphalt cement tanks, etc. (5)
'Asphalt Mixture Processing Unit.' A
continuous drum or batch mix process, including, but not limited to, a
baghouse, drag conveyor, aggregate dryer, storage silo and/or a hot screen pug
mill assembly with truck load out. An Asphalt Mixture Processing Unit can be
either stationary or portable. (6)
'Asphalt Mixture.' The mixture of hot, dried aggregate, with or without
recycled asphalt paving material, and heated asphalt cement; or cold mixture
material produced using aggregates and asphalt emulsion at ambient temperatures
that meets the required specifications. (7)
'Asphalt Storage Silo.' A structure that
stores finished, heated, asphalt mixture before it is loaded into
trucks. (8)
'Batch Mix Process.' An

Asphalt Mixture Processing Unit that heats the aggregate, screens out the
oversized aggregate, and stores the hot aggregate prior to blending the asphalt
cement and the aggregates in a mixer. (9)
'Blue Smoke.' Emissions of semi-volatile
organic hydrocarbon compounds and inorganic particulate matter, classified as

Polycyclic Organic Matter (POM), that condenses at atmospheric temperatures. These compounds can diffract light and create an associated air emission with
blueish color. (10)
'Calculated

Annual Production Level.' A calculated value determined by taking the average
of the three highest manufacturing calendar years of asphalt Mixture from the
previous five most recent calendar years at an Asphalt Mixture Processing Unit, looking back from the effective date of this Subpart, and continued on a
rolling basis thereafter. Once an Asphalt Mixture Processing Unit exceeds a
threshold for requiring controls, those controls must remain in place and
continue to operate regardless of future calculated production
levels. (11)
'Continuous Drum Mix

Process.' An Asphalt Mixture Processing Unit that heats aggregate and mixes it
with asphalt cement. (12)
'Drag

Slat Conveyor.' A conveyor commonly used in a continuous mix facility to
transport asphalt mixture from a drum mixer to storage silos. Drag slat
conveyors are sometimes called by other names such as slat conveyor and drag
conveyors. (13)
'Existing Asphalt

Mixture Manufacturing Plant.' An asphalt Mixture manufacturing plant that has
had process operations in any calendar year prior to the effective date of this

Subpart. (14)
'Low
NO
x

Burner.' A burner designed to emit nitrogen oxides
(NO
x
) at or below the limits specified in section
220-3.5 of this Subpart. (15)
'New

Asphalt Mixture Manufacturing Plant.' An Asphalt Mixture Manufacturing Plant
where a permit application for the construction of the plant was received by
the department after the effective date of this Subpart. Units meeting the
definition of Reconstructed Asphalt Mixture Processing Units shall be
considered new units. (16)
'Operation.' Those days, weeks, or months of the calendar year where asphalt
mixture is being produced and/or sold. (17)
'Pug Mill.' An apparatus used for mixing
the ingredients of hot and warm mix asphalt mixture. Typical units contain
shafts with mixing paddles that rotate. Hot, dry materials enter from above and
a spray bar injects asphalt cement into the mill. These components are mixed
prior to being loaded into a transport vehicle. (18)
'Reclaimed or Recycled Asphalt Pavement
(RAP).' Asphalt Mixture reclaimed from roads, parking lots, or other sources
that is then reprocessed either by itself or with virgin feed. (19)
'Reconstructed Asphalt Mixture

Processing Unit.' The replacement of components of an existing unit to such an
extent that the fixed capital cost of the new components exceeds 50 percent of
the fixed capital cost that would be required to construct a comparable new
source. (20)
'Warm Mix Asphalt.'
Asphalt Mixture that is produced by mixing heated aggregate with asphalt cement
and manufactured at temperatures below those that produce blue smoke as
determined by 40 CFR Part
60, Appendix A-4, Method 9, or other means of
testing. The asphalt cement includes additional binding materials and
additives, including but not limited to wax, emulsions, surfactants and
zeolites for easier pouring and spreading at reduced temperatures. Notes
